turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Well, the -- there was no -- there was no defense.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I know there wasn't because there had been no lawsuit.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Except that you say that -- that when they were given notice of the execution to follow, they then could've come up -- come in, I am just trying to --

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: At any time --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- they then come -- could have come in and your Court of common plea would have given --

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Anytime --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And said that we challenge the amount of the judgement as I understand it?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That's right.
At any time up until the Sheriff knocks that down and when they do -- when the Sheriff knocks that down at that auction sale, then their rights are cut off.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are you saying that's the Pennsylvania law might, it might not be Idaho law?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That's true.
I am not quoting Idaho law.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What has been the practice in the State of Pennsylvania in real estate in transactions of this -- of this kind where -- where the Government has a junior lien as -- they power the practice that -- that you're trying to sustain here or -- or is there a practice?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: In many, many instances -- in many -- in talking with other lawyers, they have followed this and other ones have just ignored it entirely.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Meaning by that?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: (Inaudible) Mr. Jacob.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Meaning by that that here -- and this gets to the gist of my argument.
A deed and a mortgage is a property right and that property right is governed by Pennsylvania law and Pennsylvania law in that sphere is supreme.
And this Court has said that in the case Erie Railroad versus Tompkins.
Property rights are creatures of state law and the remedies are creatures of state law.
And in this case, the apartments had a property right.
It was a defeasible one, because they had a mortgage on there or a purchase money mortgage.
And their title was subject to being defeated when they defrauded in that mortgage.
They defrauded in that mortgage and that sheriff's sale, which was regular in every respect, that sheriff's sale took away from them their property right in this property.

7403 can only be invoked to the Government if the Government -- it has to say that that property right is still in apartments and from the time of 1701 to this day, it's a law of Pennsylvania that by that sheriff's sale all rights of that mortgagor in that real estate are cut off.

Now, when they're cut off, then the lien which the Government had which attached to that property right to give it any sustenance or any vitality or any (Inaudible), it was cut off and when it was cut off, there is that lien hanging in there in a vacuum you might say.
But we don't destroy the lien.
We don't extinguish the lien.
They still have that lien, and they can collect it from those people that they have to look through another asset.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Jacob, may I insert into that, sheriff's sale cut off the lien so far as you are concerned.
That's your position, isn't it?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: No, that isn't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You're saying cut off all property interest in the mortgagor and thereby his interest, the total interest of the mortgagor went into the purchaser at the day of sale.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That's right.
Now, we have to be technical about this because we are dealing with a technical subject.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I am not hostile to the perspective here.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: All right.
Now, they had a lien, and the lien rested here on this property right.
We take away that property right.
There hangs their lien but their property right is gone.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but they flow in between your right hand and your lower low hand, your lower left hand Mr. Jacob.
They say that wasn't operating your illustration because in between where debt -- neglect of their right to have come in on your judgment as -- ascertainment.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's where the difficulty is.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Didn't Mr. Friedman stand here and tell you that he abandoned his argument about redemption?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He -- yes, he said that, but I didn't know that he abandoned that.
You can't get a judgement ex parte without any given notice to the United States.
I didn't hear him abandon that.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Well, he has no -- he can't raise that issue here now.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Aren't you suppose to raise here what's raised in the court below?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I've got to see what is -- what is the question that he wants to raise.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Here's another thing, let me point out this to the Court --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Jacob, he already has.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: -- that in -- at the trial of this case, if the Government was really sincere about wanting to have -- wanting to resell this property and thinking that they had -- they argue in their brief talking about windfall.
Well, there wasn't one since -- until the evidence produced at the trial of this case to determine the value or to establish the value of this real estate.

Now, if the Government was sincere in the beginning that they wanted to resell this in order to recapture their money out of it and pay us off, wouldn't they have established the value of the real estate?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Jacob let me read you the question which brought this case here and with your entirety and insisting that the Government should argue what it brought here and the basis on which we granted the certiorari.

Whether a sheriff's sale of real property and execution of a judgement confessed by mortgagee in a state court extinguishes a union federal tax lien on the property where the United States have not been joined as a party to the proceeding assured the federal statute.
Until I am corrected, I will see this case as turning on what is meant by the proceeding.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Well, that's a classical question but it isn't based on the facts of the case and it isn't based on the issues that were developed by the facts in this case that -- that developed at the trial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Jacobs I don't want to -- I don't want to labor the practice of your statement.
But I wonder if you tell me this.
You said that the -- that the rights become final when the -- when the sheriff says so, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That's where the property right of that mortgagor is taken away from him.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: And transferred into the purchasers of that real estate.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Now, may I ask you this, would a title insurance company guarantee the purchaser's title on this record as you have it here?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Well, on the record that I have it here, I would say that they would.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That they would not?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That they would.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That they would insure.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They would insure?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: They would insure.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: They would insure, because the Government did nothing here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: And in looking into this and looking in to the record, I think our title companies would say that we have complied.
We have done everything.
The prime purpose of that 2410 was to give the Government notice and can they say that they didn't get notice when we gave them or everything that was in the case?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Under your view, could you have proceeded to destroy the Government's lien without proceeding under 2410 at all?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: We did not destroy the Government's lien.
I want that distinctly understood.
We didn't interfere with it.
We didn't touch it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, so far as this property is concerned?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: So far as this property is concerned, our property stood out under that lien.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could you have obtained the property ex the Government's lien without resorting 2410 under your view?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: I think we could.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That's what I understood your provision was.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: But in order to -- and my argument is premised on that.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: In other words, your -- I thought your position was that basically, state procedures governed here?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That in proceedings as you did under 2410, you were doing something more than the Government -- than you were required.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: Now, we were required to do.
We -- we went to that --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do I understand that correctly?

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That's right, that's exactly right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, I think Mr. Jacob if I may say so, my brother Brennan and my brother Stewart calls my attention to your statement of the collection, and I accept that, but I may say that Mr. Friedman has a more accurate statement as I understand it.

Whether sheriff's sale et cetera, there that's the junior federal tax lien, where the United States was not originally made as a defendant in the confession of judgemental proceeding but was subsequently joined by the state court of the party defendant before the execution.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that your -- if I may think your upper and (Inaudible) within which you make property decline with the Government.

If they object to this second part because they say we should have been in on the original judgment proceeding and you yourself, as you presented the question, acknowledged that to be the issue before this Court.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: But isn't that rather moot? Now when they abandoned their proceedings under 2410.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If Mr. Friedman has any time, he will tell me what he did or didn't abandon.

turn.speaker: william_l_jacob
turn.label: Mr. William L. Jacob
turn.text: I thank you very much.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Friedman.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Just very, very briefly Mr. Chief Justice, we didn't abandon this position.
What happened was we said that -- what have been done here did not operate to divest our lien because we hadn't made a party initially.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To what, a party to what?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: We had not been made a party to a proceeding to foreclose a mortgage under 2410.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, be more specific since there are several proceedings here.
There was a proceeding in which Mr. Jacob is trying, put in the confession of judgment, which they were authorized to do out of the bond.
Now, do you mean you were not a party to that proceeding?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is precisely correct Mr. Justice, because the statutes speaks in terms of a proceeding of jurisdiction of any civil action to -- for the foreclosure of a mortgage.
And we think as the District Court held in this case that that means we must be made a party to that proceeding at the very --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Ab initio.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Ab initio precisely.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But their state procedure doesn't provide for -- for any notice to anyone on the first point.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But does require on the second part and you do that what was required under the second part and had an opportunity to -- to establish your -- your right?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where's the Government been injured?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: For one thing --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And -- and where is your - where is it violated there?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: One thing Mr. Chief Justice is under 2410, we are given the right of removal into the federal court and it seems to me when we remove is the suit for the foreclosure of the mortgage.
We can't remove to the federal court a proceeding -- a sheriff's sale.
What is contemplated we think here is a basic proceeding.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, if you removed it, wouldn't you remove it with whatever -- to the federal court with whatever rights the Government might have?

And he says that you have the right to -- to question the -- the amount that is due, the amount that was in that ex parte order, and that you could not, in any way, be prejudiced because you have a right to bring in all those things, even in the state court.
And if you took the federal court, why couldn't you -- why couldn't you have the same rights there?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, I think -- removal -- what -- the only thing we could remove at that stage of the proceedings would be execution proceeding and we think what Congress is contemplated here that the -- for the protection of the United States, it has the right to remove the whole thing to have in the first instance before any judgment has entered, which has the effect and interest of the United States to have itself be given an opportunity to participate in those things.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Could you have (Inaudible) that, we have a judgment?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I wouldn't think so Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I suppose he did have a judgement?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: He had a judgement.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if you reopen the judgment, would you then remove?
You made it there, there in state court.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I don't know whether if we reopen the judgment we could remove.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Reopen, if you havent' joined in the state court.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Into the state court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I would -- I would think that the removal would require initially before there's been any final determination.
I would if I -- just like to say one other point which I think is important.
The fact that we attempted to redeem a year later, it doesn't seem to me to indicate that we conceded that we had been properly made a party to the state court proceeding.
And it seems to be perfectly consistent common practice for litigants to try alternative remedies.
We thought that we would not -- had not been properly joined, but nevertheless, we did attempt to redeem later to protect ourselves.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: May I ask Mr. Chief Justice before we close this one question?
Is this clear under the law of Pennsylvania that a redemption where it's proper to be been made, maybe made at a sum equal to the bid at the sale or not?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice, Pennsylvania does not permit redemptions under Pennsylvania law.
Once the Sheriff has set sold, there is no right of redemption.
There is no right of redemption under Pennsylvania law to my understanding nevertheless.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll recess now.
